title: How practical is judo in a fight? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends. What kind of fights are you thinking of getting into? I can talk about my experiences as a kid, and once I’ve used it as a grown-up. You decide whether it is practical for your purposes. I am a peaceful guy and haven’t been in many fights. Beyond the practicality of learning how to fall without getting hurt (roll and slap), which can really save you from being seriously hurt, I have been in a few short scrapes. I don’t like fighting and I make it clear. But I do resolve things quickly. That’s why Judo appeals to me. I studied and got pretty decent at it, getting second place in a couple middle-scale competitions at my level. Because Judo is all about balance and getting the other person to the ground so they can be immobilized, this is not at all what your opponent will expect - maybe they’ve seen too much TV, maybe they studied a martial art where people punch each other, it doesn’t matter; Judo is very much an unexpected thing, which is what makes it useful. Note this will sound like I’m some great fighter; I’m decidedly not, particularly as a kid - I’m nerdy and back then I was short and light and lanky. The only fistfight I ever got into I lost horribly and I ended up bloody. I am not good with fists. Then I found Judo, and it appealed to me because there’s little blood, the fights gets resolved quickly, in what’s called an “ippon”(like a point/match/”the downed opponent would not be able to do anything past this”), and I don’t like hitting people or getting into scrapes. I can talk about three occasions where a bully was humiliated and Judo saved the day for me. The first time, the opponent (the typical middle school bully, larger than me at the time) was insulting me at recess at school. He pushed me once, I stood my ground while I evaluated his stance and cadence while he walked, then he got close to me to push me again. I stepped to the side, put my foot behind his and dumped him to the ground with a basic foot sweep with basically zero effort as he moved backwards after pushing me. Everyone was laughing at him. I just walked away.  Something like this, except I didn’t have to turn (I just couldn’t find the diagram), I just put my leg behind his and pushed him down, holding him by the shirt to break his fall so he wouldn’t hit the back of his head and get hurt with the pavement. A few weeks later, same guy. He jumped on my back (again, in public) and I stepped back instinctively and threw him past me by thrusting my pelvis up while ducking. He flew past me, landed with a loud “thud” and I could hear the air leaving his lungs. I really should have held him like in the diagram so he didn’t hit the cement so hard, but he surprised me and frankly pissed me off, given this was the second time he attacked me (he didn’t like that I didn’t respond to verbal taunts).  Don’t attack a Judoka from the back. We’ll throw you past us, bend and by the time you notice you’re in the ground with a very sore back, we’re in front of you and your torso is exposed to us. Again, I walked away while people laughed. That was the end of that bully, he stopped insulting or even interacting with me for a while. He tried to be my friend after, asking me to “teach him”. I was polite but ignored him. He can go to his own class, where the sensei will also teach him to be peaceful fo others. I don’t want to be responsible for a trained overly-aggressive bully, thank you very much. Once it happened as an adult. The person attacked me trying to punch me. I grappled his arm, turned around to put my back against his chest and used his own thrust to throw him over. I didn’t want to hurt the guy so I sort of “guided him” to the ground as opposed to letting him hit the pavement which would at that speed definitely broken something but instead I immobilized him pinning him to the ground. He tried to wiggle a few times, and I kept trying to verbally get him to calm down. After he agreed to calm I released him. He didn’t try again.  Good luck freeing yourself from this. Your left hand and feet are free, but you can’t hurt me with them. You try moving, we’ll spin right along with you. I didn’t choke him, that would be overkill. I just wanted him to acknowledge he was going to calm down. We are sort of facing each other so you can negotiate the release. So as you can see, it’s worked for me, but only because I don’t pick fights nor I search for them, and because it has a huge element of surprise to it, and the large size of someone else actually works to my advantage (today I’m tall but not heavy, so it doesn’t happen as often that this is needed). When things heat up, if someone is berating me, I’m quietly observing their stance (and hoping they’ll calm down - I really, again, don’t want to fight). If I’m attacked, I know exactly what to do. If they knew Judo, they’d counter and this would last a lot longer. But they often don’t, even if they’re good fighters in a bunch of other styles, so they break their balance as they must (since they’re the attacker) by thrusting at me when hands or feet to try to punch or kick. And 9 times out of 10, they’re going to be in the ground in the next couple seconds after that, no matter how big or small they are in comparison (bigger people get hurt worse simply because they’ll be flying in the air regardless and they’re heavier). So it’s great in that I know I am able to defend myself. I do have to care not to hurt the other person - a tatami (the mat) is not the same as a concrete floor. I use my training (and the muscle memory of my sensei guiding me in falls) to guide them as gently as I can towards the ground. I’m not a jerk, I don’t want them to break their skull or back against the concrete.
